+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 73.7
Prompt:
Cozy spacepunk The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The rag slips from my hand and I snatch it up, wiping the same spot on the bar counter again. Vega whisky. Double. I glance at the newcomer, who's practically melting into the worn leather booth. He’s got a face like a crumpled paper bag, eyes rimmed with exhaustion, and a tangle of tentacle-dreads that look like they’ve been through a blender. “Sure thing,” I say, trying to sound chipper, even though the Outpost is dead tonight. Dead as a space rock. I pull out a bottle of Vega, a good one, and measure out a double. It's a pricey drink, but he looks like he can afford it. “Anything to eat?” he asks, his voice rough and gravelly. “Yeah, we got synth-steak, synth-shrimp, synth-everything,” I say, gesturing to the menu board. “It’s not gourmet, but it’ll keep you alive.” He doesn’t even look at the board. “Synth-steak, please.” I nod, setting the whisky in front of him. He doesn’t touch it. He just stares at it, his gaze unfocused. “Rough day?” I ask, leaning against the bar. He shakes his head slowly, his dreads swaying with the movement. “Rough few weeks. Rough year, really.” I pour myself a glass of something amber and sweet, something to cut the edge off the Vega fumes. I’m not supposed to drink on the job, but I’m not exactly breaking any laws out here in the Andromeda rim. “What brings you to the Outpost?” I ask, taking a sip. He looks up at me, his eyes finally focusing. They’re a strange shade of violet, like the nebula outside the window. “I’m looking for someone.” “Anyone I know?” He shakes his head. “No. He’s… he’s a friend. A good friend.” “And you think he’s here?” He shrugs. “I don’t know. I just… I have a feeling.” I raise an eyebrow. “A feeling. That’s not exactly a reliable method of locating someone in an asteroid belt.” He sighs, running a hand through his dreads. “I know, I know. It’s not exactly scientific. But I don’t have a lot of options.” The synth-steak arrives, sizzling on a plate. He picks at it with a fork, pushing it around the plate. “What’s his name?” I ask. “Kai.” Kai. I know that name. Everyone knows that name. Kai is a legend around here. He’s the one who found the rich vein of iridium on this asteroid belt. The one who built the Outpost. The one who made everyone rich. “Kai?” I say, trying to keep the surprise out of my voice. “You know Kai?” He looks up at me, startled. “You know him?” “Everyone knows him,” I say. “He’s… he’s a big deal around here.” He nods, but he doesn’t look convinced. “Yeah, I guess so. But he’s not a big deal to me. He’s just… Kai.” I take another sip of my drink. “Well, he hasn’t been around for a while. Not since the accident.” His fork clatters against the plate. “Accident? What accident?” “The mining accident,” I say. “A few months back. It was pretty bad. A whole section of the mine collapsed. A lot of people died.” He stares at me, his face paling. “Kai… was he…?” “We don’t know,” I say. “They never found his body. Officially, he’s listed as missing, presumed dead.” He sets down his fork, pushing the synth-steak away. “But… but he’s not dead. I know he’s not.” “You can’t be sure of that,” I say. “It’s been months. He could be… anywhere.” He shakes his head, his violet eyes blazing. “He wouldn’t just leave. Not without telling me. Not without saying goodbye.” He reaches for the Vega, taking a long swallow. The bottle is half empty when he sets it down. “Look, I don’t know what happened to Kai,” I say. “But if you’re looking for him, you’re going to have to start somewhere. The mine’s the obvious place to start.” He looks at me, his eyes filled with a desperate hope. “You know the mine? You know where it is?” “I know where it used to be,” I say. “It’s… it’s not what it used to be.” He looks confused. “What do you mean?” I take another sip of my drink, feeling the warmth spread through my chest. “Kai shut it down. After the accident. Said it was too dangerous. He moved everything to a new site, further out. He hasn’t let anyone in since.” He stares at me, his face falling. “He shut it down? He didn’t tell me.” “He probably didn’t want to worry you,” I say. “He was worried about everyone.” He nods slowly, as if he’s trying to process what I’m saying. “So… the mine’s empty? There’s no one there?” “No one but the security bots,” I say. “And they’re programmed to shoot first, ask questions never.” He looks down at his hands, his dreads falling around him like a curtain. “So… there’s no way in?” I shrug. “There’s always a way in. But it’s not going to be easy.” He looks up at me, his violet eyes pleading. “You… you could help me, couldn’t you? You know the Outpost. You know the people here. Maybe you know someone who could help me get in.” I stare at him, my mind racing. Helping him get into Kai’s mine could be a disaster. But something about him… something about those violet eyes… makes me want to help him. “I’ll see what I can do,” I say. “But I can’t promise anything.” He smiles, a small, tired smile. “Thank you. Thank you so much.” He takes another drink of the Vega, then sets the bottle down. “I’m going to need more of that.” I nod, pouring him another double. He doesn’t even flinch. He just stares at the whisky, as if he’s trying to find an answer in its amber depths. I wipe the same spot on the bar counter again. The rag slips from my hand. I snatch it up, wiping the spot again. I don’t know why I’m doing it. Maybe it’s because I’m nervous. Maybe it’s because I’m scared. Maybe it’s because I’m already regretting this. But whatever the reason, I know one thing for sure: helping this stranger find Kai is going to be a whole lot more complicated than I thought.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully establishes a cozy spacepunk atmosphere at "The Last Outpost" with Nettle (Nets) as the bartender protagonist. The writing follows the first-person, present-tense perspective as requested and introduces conflict through the mysterious stranger searching for Kai, a legendary figure who has disappeared after a mining accident. The dialogue comprises roughly 60% of the text as instructed, though some of it feels functional rather than revealing character depth. The conversation establishes the central conflict—the stranger's search for his missing friend Kai—but doesn't delve deeply into either character's motivations or backgrounds. The dialogue serves its purpose but lacks distinctive voices; both characters speak in a similar cadence. The descriptive elements create a serviceable atmosphere of a space bar in an asteroid belt, though the imagery could be more vivid and specific to this unique setting. The "tentacled dreads" of the stranger are mentioned but not fully integrated into the worldbuilding. The descriptions of the Vega whisky and synth-food establish the setting but don't transport the reader fully into this alien environment. The narrative successfully introduces conflict without resolving it, as requested. The tension builds around the missing Kai, the dangerous abandoned mine, and Nettle's reluctant decision to help the stranger. However, the stakes remain somewhat vague—we don't know why finding Kai is so important to the stranger beyond friendship, or why Nettle would risk helping him. The prose is generally clean and readable, though it relies on some clichés ("face like a crumpled paper bag," "dead as a space rock"). The repetition of wiping the bar at the beginning and end creates a nice framing device, suggesting Nettle's nervous habit and foreshadowing trouble. Character development is minimal but sufficient for a chapter. Nettle's reluctance and curiosity come through, though her "past life" mentioned in the prompt isn't explored. The stranger remains largely a cipher, defined mainly by his desperation and violet eyes. Overall, the piece fulfills the basic requirements of the prompt but doesn't fully capitalize on the rich potential of the cozy spacepunk setting or the characters' emotional depths. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 15 Nuanced Characters: 12 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13 Elegant Prose: 14 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 7 Tell-Don't-Show: 6 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 14 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 14 Overall Impression: 14

+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 52.5
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps slipping off my shoulder, and I keep readjusting it. It's a constant reminder that I’m carrying everything I own in this stupid thing. It's also a reminder that I’m alone. Completely and utterly alone. I'm standing on a corner in the French Quarter, staring at the wrought-iron balconies dripping with bougainvillea. Tourists are everywhere, snapping photos and speaking in languages I don't understand. The air smells like beignets and stale beer. It's a sensory overload. I feel like I'm on another planet. This is New Orleans. This is where I'm supposed to start over. I'm supposed to be brave. I'm supposed to be strong. But I'm just…lost. I’ve been wandering around for hours, trying to find somewhere to go, somewhere to sleep. I've walked past strip clubs and art galleries, jazz clubs and souvenir shops. I've seen people who look like they're having the time of their lives, and people who look like they're on the edge of a breakdown. I’ve seen everything, and nothing. I’m so tired. My feet hurt, and my head is pounding. I’m hungry, and I’m thirsty. I wish I could just curl up in a corner and sleep. But I can't. I have to keep moving. I have to keep searching. I stop at a coffee shop and order a large iced coffee. I sit at a table outside and watch the people go by. I’m trying to look normal, but I know I don't. I’m wearing the same clothes I’ve had on for two days: a black band t-shirt, ripped jeans, and combat boots. My hair is a mess, and I haven't showered. I probably smell like sweat and anxiety. I take a sip of my coffee, but it doesn't help. I feel numb. Suddenly, I see him. He’s sitting on a bench across the street, leaning against the wall. He looks about my age, maybe a year or two older. He’s wearing a black hoodie and ripped jeans, just like me. He has dark hair and eyes, and a nose ring. He looks…familiar. I can’t explain it, but something about him draws me in. Maybe it's the fact that he looks as lost as I feel. Or maybe it’s because he’s the first person I’ve seen who isn’t a tourist. I finish my coffee and stand up. I take a deep breath, and then I cross the street. "Hey," I say. He looks up at me, his eyes widening slightly. He looks me over, from my head to my toes. "Hey," he says. "You new here?" "Yeah," I say. "Just got here last night." "Me too," he says. "I came from…somewhere else." He doesn’t elaborate. "I can see that," I say, trying to sound casual. He smiles, a small, sad smile. "I'm Kai." "Taylor," I say. "Nice to meet you, Taylor," he says. "What brings you to New Orleans?" "Uh…escape," I say. "I ran away from home." His smile fades. "Me too." We sit in silence for a moment, both of us staring at the ground. "It's…scary, isn't it?" he says finally. "Yeah," I say. "It is." "I didn't think it would be," he says. "I thought it would be…fun. An adventure." "I thought so too," I say. "But it's not." "It's lonely," he says. "It is," I say. We sit in silence again, the sounds of the city swirling around us. "So…what are you going to do?" he asks. I shrug. "I don't know. I'm trying to figure that out." "Me too," he says. "I don't have anywhere to go. I don't have any money." "Me neither," I say. He looks at me, his eyes searching mine. "Do you want to…hang out?" I hesitate. I don't know him. I don't know if I can trust him. But I'm so lonely, and I'm so tired. "Okay," I say. He smiles. "Cool. Let's go find some food." We walk down the street, past the crowds of tourists. Kai seems to know where he's going. He leads me to a small, hole-in-the-wall restaurant. It's crowded, but we manage to find a table. "What do you want?" he asks. I look at the menu, but I don't know what to order. Everything sounds good. "I don't know," I say. "Anything." He orders for both of us: jambalaya and gumbo. When the food comes, we dig in. It's delicious. "This is amazing," I say, mopping up the last of the sauce with a piece of bread. "Yeah," he says. "It is." We talk for a while, mostly about ourselves. I tell him about my family, about how they didn't accept me when I came out as trans. He tells me about his own family, about how he ran away because he couldn't stand being around them anymore. "They didn't understand me," he says. "They didn't want to understand me." "I know what that's like," I say. He nods. "It's…it's hard." "It is," I say. We finish eating and leave the restaurant. The sun is starting to set, and the sky is turning a beautiful shade of orange. "So…where are you going to sleep tonight?" he asks. I shake my head. "I don't know. I haven't thought about it." "Me neither," he says. "I was thinking…maybe we could crash at the park? There's a park over there." He points down the street. I hesitate. Sleeping in a park sounds…rough. But I don't have any other options. "Okay," I say. We walk to the park. It's deserted, except for a few homeless people huddled under trees. We find a spot on a bench and sit down. "It's not ideal," Kai says. "No," I say. "It's not." We sit in silence for a while, watching the stars come out. "I'm glad I met you," I say finally. He looks at me, his eyes softening. "Me too, Taylor. Me too." I lean my head on his shoulder. He puts his arm around me. We sit like that for a long time, just holding each other, until the city lights begin to fade and the park falls silent. I don’t know what the future holds for me, or for Kai. But for tonight, I’m not alone. And that’s enough. The strap on my backpack slips off my shoulder again, but I don’t bother readjusting it. I don't feel like moving. I just want to stay here, with Kai, and forget about everything else. I close my eyes and let myself drift off to sleep, feeling safe for the first time in days.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The piece follows Taylor, a trans teen who has run away from home after coming out to an unsupportive family. The narrative captures their first day in New Orleans after being dropped off by a ride. The writing establishes Taylor's vulnerability and disorientation in a new city before introducing Kai, another runaway with whom Taylor forms an immediate connection. The writing adheres to most of the prompt requirements, using first-person perspective and mixed tense. It incorporates Taylor's internal monologue and includes dialogue with Kai, the main character Taylor meets. However, the story falls short in several areas. While it establishes that Kai is also a runaway, it doesn't fully develop the "issues and secrets" aspect mentioned in the prompt. The narrative also doesn't deeply explore the dangers of Taylor's new environment or create a sense that Taylor doesn't know who to trust - Taylor seems to trust Kai almost immediately with minimal hesitation. The character actions are somewhat believable but simplified. Taylor's quick trust in Kai feels rushed rather than earned through meaningful interaction. While the initial wariness is mentioned ("I hesitate. I don't know him. I don't know if I can trust him."), it's dismissed in the very next sentence without sufficient justification. The characters lack nuance - they're presented as generic runaways without distinctive personalities or complex motivations. The voice is consistent but lacks distinctiveness. Taylor's narration could belong to almost any teen character; it doesn't have unique cadences or expressions that would make it feel like a specific person's voice. The imagery is basic, with some standard New Orleans references (beignets, wrought-iron balconies, jambalaya) but lacks vivid, sensory details that would bring the setting to life. The emotional engagement is moderate. We understand Taylor's loneliness and fear, but these emotions aren't deeply explored or rendered in ways that feel fresh. The emotional complexity is limited - Taylor's conflicting emotions about their identity, family rejection, and new freedom aren't fully developed. The narrative tells us Taylor has "intense & conflicting emotions" rather than showing this complexity through specific thoughts, physical sensations, or behaviors. The dialogue is functional but weak, with exchanges that feel generic rather than revealing character. Lines like "It's scary, isn't it?" and "Yeah, it is" don't reveal much about either character or advance the plot in meaningful ways. The ending feels incongruent with the established situation - Taylor suddenly feels "safe for the first time in days" while sleeping on a park bench with a stranger, which doesn't align with the vulnerability of their situation. This positive resolution feels unearned given the precarious circumstances. Overall, the piece delivers a basic narrative that follows the prompt's outline but lacks depth, distinctive voice, and emotional complexity. It relies on telling rather than showing and doesn't fully capture the danger and uncertainty of Taylor's situation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 14 Believable Character Actions: 11 Nuanced Characters: 8 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 13 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 10 Elegant Prose: 11 Emotionally Engaging: 12 Emotionally Complex: 9 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 14 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 13 Unearned Transformations: 12 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 11 Overall Impression: 11
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 14.0, Believable Character Actions: 11.0, Nuanced Characters: 8.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 13.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 10.0, Elegant Prose: 11.0, Emotionally Engaging: 12.0, Emotionally Complex: 9.0, Coherent: 15.0, Meandering: 8.0, Weak Dialogue: 14.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 13.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 14.0, Amateurish: 12.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 13.0, Unearned Transformations: 12.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 9.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 11.0, Overall Impression: 11.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 42.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Midas looked at Chewy, the animatronic stuffed koala, perched on the edge of the table. Chewy was, without a doubt, the most advanced piece of technology Midas had encountered since the Collapse. He didn't know who had made Chewy or why, but he did know that Chewy was the only thing that kept him from going completely mad. “So,” Midas said, scratching his chin, “we’re going to the ruins of the old library today. I hear there are books there, actual books. Not just scraps of paper with scribbles on them. Books. With pages.” Chewy blinked his button eyes and let out a little whirring sound. “Chewy needs a hug. Chewy loves hugs.” “You always say that,” Midas grumbled, “even when I’m about to get eaten by a wolf.” Chewy didn't respond, just tilted his head. He was programmed with a limited vocabulary, mostly consisting of pre-Collapse advertising slogans that no one fully understood. “Chewy needs a hug. Chewy loves hugs. Chewy makes your day better. Chewy is your best friend.” Midas sighed. He’d long since stopped trying to make sense of Chewy’s ramblings. “Right. Well, let’s get going then.” They set off into the overgrown ruins of what had once been a bustling city. The buildings were crumbling, the streets choked with weeds, and the air thick with dust. Midas carried a rusty machete and a battered backpack, while Chewy perched on his shoulder, occasionally letting out a random slogan. “Chewy is your best friend. Chewy is your number one. Chewy is the best.” The library was a massive stone building, half-buried in rubble. Midas hacked his way through the overgrown vines that covered the entrance, while Chewy watched with wide eyes. “Wow,” he said, “Chewy sees so many colors. Chewy loves colors.” Midas ignored him and stepped inside. The air inside was cool and damp, and the silence was almost oppressive. Rows upon rows of shelves stretched into the gloom, filled with books. He ran his fingers along the spines, feeling the smooth leather and the rough paper. “Amazing,” he whispered, “they’re all still here.” He began pulling books off the shelves, stuffing them into his backpack. Chewy, meanwhile, was bouncing around excitedly. “Chewy is having so much fun. Chewy loves fun. Chewy makes your day better.” Suddenly, a loud crash echoed through the library. Midas froze, his heart pounding in his chest. He slowly turned around, machete raised. “What was that?” he asked, his voice trembling. Chewy didn’t answer, but he let out a high-pitched squeak. “Chewy is scared. Chewy needs a hug.” Midas cursed under his breath. He crept forward, cautiously scanning the shadows. Then, he saw them. Three figures, clad in ragged clothes and armed with rusty pipes, were emerging from the darkness. They were scavengers, raiders, the kind of people who would kill for a single book. “Well, well, well,” the leader sneered, “look what we have here. A little bookworm.” Midas swallowed hard. “I don’t have anything you want.” “Oh, we think you do,” the leader said, taking a step forward. “We think you have books.” Midas shook his head. “No. These are just for me. I’m just… studying.” The leader laughed. “Studying, are you? Well, you’re going to study a lot harder now.” He raised his pipe and lunged at Midas. Midas dodged the blow, slashing out with his machete. The scavenger stumbled back, clutching his arm. His companions rushed forward, but Midas was ready for them. He fought with a desperate ferocity, swinging his machete wildly and dodging their attacks. Chewy, meanwhile, was squeaking and chirping frantically. “Chewy needs a hug. Chewy is your best friend. Chewy is the best.” Midas ignored him, focused on the fight. He managed to fend off the scavengers, but he was getting tired. His arms were aching, his chest heaving, and his breath coming in ragged gasps. Just as the leader was about to strike, Midas heard a loud buzzing sound. He looked up to see a swarm of bees pouring out of a hole in the ceiling. They descended upon the scavengers, stinging them mercilessly. The scavengers screamed and flailed, trying to brush the bees away. Midas seized the opportunity and ran, dragging Chewy with him. They burst out of the library and into the overgrown streets. Midas didn’t stop running until he was far away from the ruins. He collapsed against a crumbling wall, gasping for breath. “Are you okay?” he asked Chewy. Chewy blinked his button eyes. “Chewy is okay. Chewy loves you.” Midas didn’t have the energy to argue. He just sat there, leaning against the wall, listening to the buzzing of the bees and the distant cries of the scavengers. “I think,” he said, “we should go home.” Chewy nodded enthusiastically. “Chewy loves going home. Chewy loves home. Chewy is your best friend.” They made their way back to Midas’s makeshift home, a small hut built from scavenged materials. As they approached, Midas noticed something strange. His hut was surrounded by a crowd of people. He cautiously approached the crowd, Chewy perched on his shoulder. “What’s going on?” he asked. A woman in the crowd stepped forward. “We heard you fought off some scavengers,” she said. “We need your help.” “My help?” Midas asked, bewildered. “I’m just a… a bookworm.” “We’re being threatened by another group of scavengers,” the woman explained. “They’re much bigger and stronger than the ones you fought. We need someone who can defend us.” Midas looked at Chewy, who was staring at the crowd with wide eyes. “Chewy is your best friend. Chewy is your number one.” “I don’t know,” Midas said. “I’m not a fighter. I’m just a…” “A hero,” the woman finished for him. “That’s what you are. A hero.” Midas hesitated. He wasn’t a hero. He was just a man trying to survive in a world that had gone mad. But he couldn’t just stand by and let these people be hurt. He took a deep breath. “Alright,” he said. “I’ll help you.” The crowd cheered. Midas felt a surge of adrenaline course through his veins. He was going to fight. He was going to defend these people. He turned to Chewy. “Ready?” he asked. Chewy nodded vigorously. “Chewy is ready. Chewy is your best friend. Chewy makes your day better.” Midas smiled grimly. “Let’s do this.” They marched into battle, Midas wielding his machete and Chewy perched on his shoulder, chirping and squeaking encouragement. The fight was fierce and brutal, but Midas and Chewy fought with a surprising ferocity. The scavengers were bigger and stronger, but they were also disorganized and poorly equipped. Midas and Chewy managed to hold them off, inflicting heavy casualties. Finally, the scavengers retreated, leaving behind a trail of wounded and dead. The people cheered, lifting Midas onto their shoulders. “You saved us!” they shouted. “You’re a hero!” Midas felt a strange mixture of pride and exhaustion. He had done it. He had saved these people. He had become a hero. He looked at Chewy, who was blinking his button eyes and letting out a random slogan. “Chewy is your best friend. Chewy is your number one.” Midas chuckled. “You know,” he said, “you’re not so bad, after all.” Chewy chirped happily. “Chewy loves you. Chewy loves hugs.” Midas shook his head and smiled. He might be a bookworm, a coward, and a klutz, but he had a koala for a buddy. And that, he thought, was something. They walked back to their hut, the crowd following behind them. Midas felt a warmth spread through his chest. He had found a purpose in this broken world. He had found a family. He looked at Chewy, perched on his shoulder. “Chewy,” he said, “I think we should go back to the library tomorrow.” Chewy blinked his button eyes. “Chewy needs a hug. Chewy loves hugs.” Midas hugged him tightly. “You’re right,” he said. “Chewy needs a hug.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story attempts to capture Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style in a post-apocalyptic setting, but falls short in several key areas. While it establishes the basic premise of Midas and his animatronic koala companion Chewy, the execution lacks the satirical depth, clever wordplay, and subversive humor that characterizes Pratchett's work. The story begins promisingly with the introduction of the odd pair and their mission to find books, but quickly devolves into a generic post-apocalyptic adventure. The narrative structure is problematic - rather than focusing on "the day's mission" as requested, it introduces a second conflict with the townspeople that feels rushed and tacked on. This creates a disjointed narrative that doesn't properly return the characters "worse for wear" to their home base as specified. Chewy's character is particularly one-dimensional, limited to repeating the same few phrases throughout the story. While this could have been played for comedic effect in a Pratchett-esque manner, it instead becomes repetitive and fails to develop. The koala lacks the sardonic wit or unexpected wisdom that would make him an interesting foil to Midas. Midas himself undergoes an unearned transformation from "hapless protagonist with a knack for finding trouble" to heroic defender of a village in a matter of paragraphs. This abrupt shift contradicts the prompt's characterization and feels forced rather than organic to the story. The prose is serviceable but lacks the distinctive voice and clever turns of phrase that define Pratchett's style. There are few metaphors, no footnotes, minimal wordplay, and none of the philosophical asides that make Pratchett's work so distinctive. The humor is largely absent, with no real satirical elements or subversion of post-apocalyptic tropes. The action sequences are told rather than shown, with generic descriptions like "The fight was fierce and brutal" instead of specific, vivid details that would bring the scene to life. The dialogue is functional but lacks wit or depth. The ending is incongruently positive, with Midas suddenly finding "purpose" and "family" in a way that feels unearned given the story's events. This happy resolution contradicts the prompt's request for characters returning "worse for wear." Overall, while the story establishes a basic post-apocalyptic scenario with the requested characters, it fails to capture Pratchett's distinctive style or fulfill the narrative arc specified in the prompt. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 10 Believable Character Actions: 9 Nuanced Characters: 7 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 8 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 9 Elegant Prose: 8 Emotionally Engaging: 9 Emotionally Complex: 6 Coherent: 11 Meandering: 12 Weak Dialogue: 13 Tell-Don't-Show: 14 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 7 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 15 Unearned Transformations: 16 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 7 Sentences Flow Naturally: 12 Overall Reader Engagement: 9 Overall Impression: 8
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 10.0, Believable Character Actions: 9.0, Nuanced Characters: 7.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 8.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 9.0, Elegant Prose: 8.0, Emotionally Engaging: 9.0, Emotionally Complex: 6.0, Coherent: 11.0, Meandering: 12.0, Weak Dialogue: 13.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 14.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13.0, Amateurish: 12.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 7.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 15.0, Unearned Transformations: 16.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 7.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 12.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 9.0, Overall Impression: 8.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 58.8
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The rain hammered against the windows of the bookstore, a relentless Welsh downpour that blurred the world outside into a grey, indistinct wash. Inside, the air smelled of old paper and dust, a comforting, familiar scent to Eluned Morgan, owner of Ystafell Llyfrau – The Book Room. She was shelving a new shipment of Welsh language poetry, her fingers tracing the embossed covers with a practiced gentleness, when the bell above the door chimed. Eluned looked up, expecting a regular customer, perhaps Mrs. Davies from down the street, or one of the local schoolteachers. Instead, she found herself staring into the eyes of Rhys Davies, the most famous actor in Wales. He was a whirlwind of apologies, a cascade of apologies, really. “Oh, I’m so sorry to just barge in like this,” he said, his voice a smooth, honeyed baritone. He was dressed in a dark, tailored suit, completely out of place in the cosy, cluttered bookshop. “The paparazzi are… relentless today. I just needed somewhere to hide for a bit.” Eluned blinked. Rhys Davies? Here? In her little bookstore? He was the star of a hugely popular historical drama, and his face was plastered on every magazine cover in the country. She’d seen him on television, of course, but had never imagined he’d actually step foot in Ystafell Llyfrau. “No problem,” she said, her voice a little breathy. “Take a seat. I’ll get you a coffee.” She gestured towards a small armchair tucked into a corner, piled high with cushions. Rhys sank into it with a sigh, running a hand through his dark hair. “Thank you,” he said, his eyes scanning the shelves with an air of genuine interest. “This is… lovely. So much better than the sterile environment of a hotel lobby.” Eluned returned with a steaming mug of coffee and a plate of shortbread biscuits. “Help yourself.” He took a biscuit, nibbling on it delicately. “You have excellent taste,” he said, his gaze lingering on her for a moment. “In books, and in shortbread.” Eluned felt her cheeks flush. She busied herself with arranging the poetry books, trying to ignore the way his eyes followed her movements. “I try,” she mumbled. “So, what are you reading these days?” Rhys asked, leaning forward slightly. “Oh, just some Welsh poetry,” she said, gesturing to the shelf she’d been working on. “The latest collection by Eirlys Roberts.” Rhys nodded thoughtfully. “I’ve heard of her. She’s quite well-regarded, isn’t she?” “Very,” Eluned said, straightening up. “She’s a brilliant poet. Her work is… evocative.” “Evocative,” Rhys repeated, his lips curving into a smile. “That’s a good word. I’ve always been drawn to poetry. It’s a shame I can’t write it myself.” “I’m sure you could,” Eluned said, surprised by her own boldness. “If you put your mind to it.” Rhys laughed, a rich, melodious sound that made Eluned’s stomach flutter. “I’m an actor, not a poet,” he said. “My mind is already full of lines and characters. I’d probably end up writing a sonnet about a Roman centurion or something.” “Or a Welsh king,” Eluned suggested, a mischievous glint in her eye. Rhys’s smile widened. “Now that I could get into,” he said. “I’ve always had a soft spot for Welsh history. I’m actually a bit of a history buff, myself.” Eluned’s eyebrows shot up. “Really? What’s your favourite period?” “The medieval period,” Rhys said without hesitation. “The stories, the battles, the castles… it’s all so fascinating.” Eluned nodded enthusiastically. “Me too! I’m particularly interested in the Princes of Gwynedd.” Rhys’s eyes lit up. “Llywelyn the Great! Llywelyn ap Gruffudd! They were incredible men.” “They were,” Eluned agreed. “And their stories are so often overlooked.” “Exactly!” Rhys said, leaning forward even further. “They should be taught in schools. Everyone should know about them.” They talked for what felt like hours, lost in a shared passion for Welsh history. Rhys was surprisingly knowledgeable, and Eluned found herself genuinely impressed by his enthusiasm. She’d expected him to be a superficial celebrity, but he was intelligent and engaging, with a genuine interest in the world around him. “I’m sorry to interrupt,” Eluned said, glancing at the clock. “I should probably get back to work.” Rhys looked genuinely disappointed. “Oh, really? Already?” “I’m afraid so,” Eluned said, her voice softening. “It’s been lovely talking to you, though.” “It has,” Rhys agreed, his eyes searching hers. “Truly lovely.” He stood up, stretching his long limbs. “I should probably be going,” he said. “The paparazzi will be here any minute.” “Of course,” Eluned said, feeling a pang of regret. “I’ll keep the coffee warm for you.” Rhys smiled, a genuine, unguarded smile that made Eluned’s heart skip a beat. “Thank you,” he said. “You’re a very kind person, Eluned Morgan.” He reached out and gently brushed a stray strand of hair from her cheek, his fingers lingering for a moment. Eluned’s breath hitched, and she felt a sudden, overwhelming desire to lean into his touch. But she didn’t. Instead, she stepped back, her cheeks burning. “I… I should get back to work,” she stammered. Rhys nodded, his smile fading slightly. “Right. Of course.” He hesitated for a moment, then said, “Perhaps I’ll see you around?” Eluned nodded, unable to speak. He turned and walked towards the door, pausing to look back at her one last time. “Goodbye, Eluned,” he said, his voice low and husky. Then he was gone, and the bell above the door chimed again, shattering the silence. Eluned stood there for a long moment, her hand still tingling where Rhys had touched her. She felt strangely disoriented, as if she’d woken up from a dream. She turned back to the poetry shelf, but her mind was still reeling from their conversation. Rhys Davies, the most famous actor in Wales, had been in her bookstore. And he’d talked to her, really talked to her, about something she was passionate about. She picked up a volume of Eirlys Roberts’ poetry, her fingers tracing the embossed cover. She opened it at random and began to read, her voice barely a whisper. “*I am the wind, the rain, the sea, The mountains, the valleys, the land you see. I am the spirit of this ancient place, The heartbeat of a forgotten race.*” She closed the book, her heart aching with a longing she couldn’t explain. Rhys Davies was a world away from her, a world of glitz and glamour and adoring fans. She was just a small-town bookseller, content with her quiet life and her love of Welsh history. But for a brief, magical moment, they’d shared something special. Something that had stirred something deep within her, something that she’d never felt before. She looked out the window, watching the rain fall. She wondered if Rhys Davies was thinking about her, too. And she wondered if she would ever see him again. The bell above the door chimed, and Eluned turned to see a young woman standing in the doorway, a bright, inquisitive smile on her face. “Excuse me,” the woman said, “Do you have any books on Welsh mythology?” Eluned smiled back, her heart feeling a little lighter. “Of course,” she said. “Right this way.” She walked towards the back of the shop, her mind still filled with images of Rhys Davies and their conversation. But she pushed them aside, focusing on the customer in front of her. She had a bookstore to run, and books to sell. And perhaps, just perhaps, a little bit of magic to share.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This romance scene set in a Welsh bookstore presents a chance encounter between a famous actor and a bookstore owner. The piece succeeds in establishing the setting and creating a plausible scenario for their meeting, but falls short in several key areas. The dialogue, which was specifically requested to be the primary focus, is relatively sparse and generic. While there are conversations between the characters, they lack the distinct voices requested in the prompt. Rhys's dialogue doesn't strongly convey his character as "a rogue with a fragile ego" - his speech patterns are polite and conventional rather than distinctively charming or roguish. Similarly, Eluned's dialogue doesn't clearly show her superficial immunity to his charm. The chemistry between the characters feels told rather than shown. We're informed that Eluned is "inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered" but this is conveyed through narrative exposition rather than through dialogue or subtle behavioral cues. The narrative repeatedly tells us about Eluned's reactions (her heart skipping, cheeks burning, etc.) rather than revealing them through her words or actions. The characters' shared interest in Welsh history provides a reasonable foundation for connection, but the conversation itself is rather generic. Their exchange about Welsh kings and history lacks the "undercurrent of unspoken chemistry" requested in the prompt. The dialogue doesn't crackle with tension or reveal much about their characters. The prose is generally competent but occasionally veers into cliché ("her heart skip a beat," "her cheeks burning"). The ending feels somewhat forced, with the introduction of a new customer serving as an abrupt conclusion rather than a natural resolution to the scene. The piece does succeed in establishing a cozy Welsh bookstore setting and creates a plausible scenario for the characters' meeting. The Welsh cultural elements (poetry, history, language) add authenticity to the setting. However, the characters lack the specific traits outlined in the prompt, and their interaction doesn't fully capture the dynamic requested. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 12 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 10 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 14 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 11 Emotionally Complex: 9 Coherent: 15 Meandering: 8 Weak Dialogue: 12 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 11 Amateurish: 8 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8 Unearned Transformations: 7 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 11 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 12 Overall Impression: 12

+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 67.2
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold's door swung inward with a groan of ancient hinges, releasing a rush of cool, damp air. Aya, Katra, and Simeon stepped inside, the light from their lanterns barely piercing the oppressive gloom. The silence was immediate and absolute, broken only by the rhythmic drip of water somewhere deep within the stone labyrinth. It was unsettling, unnatural, the opposite of the frantic energy they'd expected. Aya’s hand tightened on her own lantern, her knuckles white. "This is... odd," she murmured, her voice echoing faintly. Katra, a hulking woman with a shaved head and a network of scars tracing her arms, sniffed the air. "Too quiet," she agreed, her voice a low rumble. "Something's not right." Simeon, a slender man with a perpetually worried expression, adjusted his spectacles nervously. "Perhaps they've fled?" he suggested, though his tone lacked conviction. "The raid must have been quite... disruptive." Aya shook her head. "No. The guild wouldn't abandon the Scythan artifact so easily." She took a tentative step forward, her lantern casting dancing shadows on the rough-hewn walls. "Let's be careful." They advanced cautiously, their lanterns illuminating a narrow corridor that twisted and turned, descending deeper into the earth. The air grew colder and heavier with each step, a damp chill that seeped into their bones. The silence was broken by the occasional scuttling sound, the rustle of unseen creatures in the darkness. Suddenly, the corridor opened into a vast chamber, lit by flickering braziers that cast an eerie orange glow on the walls. The chamber was filled with crates and barrels, stacked haphazardly, and in the center stood a raised platform, upon which rested a single, ornate chest. But it wasn't the chest that caught Aya's attention. It was the figure standing before it, bathed in the flickering light. The woman was tall and imposing, dressed in a dark velvet gown that flowed around her like liquid. Her hair, once a vibrant auburn, was now streaked with grey and pulled back tightly from her face. Her eyes, however, were as sharp and vibrant as ever, burning with a cold, calculating intelligence. It was Madame Evangeline, the guild leader. And she was not in chains. "Well, well, well," she purred, her voice like silk laced with venom. "Look what the cat dragged in." Aya froze, her heart hammering against her ribs. She'd expected resistance, but not this. "Madame Evangeline," she managed, her voice trembling slightly. "We... we thought you were arrested." Evangeline let out a harsh, mocking laugh. "Arrested? My dear, you flatter the constables. They were mere pawns in a game I orchestrated. A distraction, if you will." She gestured to the guards surrounding her, a motley crew of hulking thugs armed with knives and clubs. "My loyal guards, who, unlike your little band of misfits, actually believe in the Morska." Katra and Simeon instinctively moved to Aya's side, their hands reaching for their own weapons. But Evangeline raised a hand, silencing them. "No need for violence, my pretties. You're already prisoners." Aya swallowed, her throat suddenly dry. She could feel the weight of Katra and Simeon's eyes on her, a mixture of fear and betrayal. She hadn't told them about her role in the guild. She hadn't wanted them to know. "You knew?" Simeon stammered, his spectacles sliding down his nose. Aya nodded, unable to meet his gaze. "I... I've been helping the guild for some time now. I thought... I thought I could change things from the inside." Evangeline's lips curled into a cruel smile. "How noble. And how foolish. You thought you could tame the beast, little aristocrat? You thought you could control the darkness within you?" She took a step closer, her eyes boring into Aya's. "You are a fool, child. And a dangerous one." Aya's breath hitched in her throat. She could feel the power within her, the dark energy that surged through her veins, threatening to break free. She fought to keep it under control, focusing on the woman before her, on the need to survive. "I can be useful to you," she said, her voice regaining some of its strength. "I have skills you need. Immateria magick is rare, and I'm one of the few who can wield it." Evangeline tilted her head, considering her. "Indeed. A most interesting proposition. But what guarantee do I have that you won't turn on me?" Aya hesitated. She knew she was walking a tightrope, one wrong step and she could plummet to her death. But she had to try. "I can prove my loyalty. I can help you retrieve the Scythan artifact." "And what makes you think you can do that?" Evangeline countered. "You're just a girl. A pampered, sheltered girl who's never known a day of hardship." "I've been training," Aya insisted, her voice rising slightly. "I've been studying the artifact. I know its weaknesses." "Weaknesses?" Evangeline scoffed. "The Scythan artifact is beyond your comprehension, child. It is an ancient relic, imbued with powers that defy mortal understanding." "I know enough," Aya said, her voice hardening. "I know that the artifact is protected by a complex spell, and that the key to breaking it lies within the guild's vaults." Evangeline's eyes narrowed. "So you know about the key." Aya nodded. "I've seen it. It's a small, silver locket, inscribed with runes." "And you know where it is?" "I do." Evangeline's smile widened, revealing a row of sharp, predatory teeth. "Then perhaps you are not as foolish as I thought. But let us not get ahead of ourselves. You have proven nothing yet." She gestured to one of her guards. "Take her. Strip her. Let us see if she truly is who she claims to be." Two of the guards stepped forward and seized Aya's arms, dragging her toward a nearby table. She struggled against their grip, but they were too strong. She could feel their rough hands tearing at her clothes, stripping her of her finery. The guards ripped away her gloves, exposing her hands, her knuckles bruised and calloused from years of training. They pulled off her boots, revealing her bare feet, toughened by countless hours spent running through the streets of the city. Finally, they reached her mask, the intricately carved silver mask that concealed her identity. With a swift, brutal tug, they ripped it from her face, exposing her features to the light. Evangeline's eyes widened in surprise. "Aya," she breathed, her voice barely audible. "The Lady Aya de Valois?" Aya's heart sank. She'd been caught. Her secret was out. There was no going back now. "You're the daughter of the late Madame de Valois," Evangeline continued, her voice regaining its composure. "The infamous immateria witch who was hanged for consorting with dark entities." Aya flinched, the memory of her mother's execution searing through her mind. "That was a lie," she whispered, her voice trembling. "My mother was innocent." "Perhaps," Evangeline said, her gaze unwavering. "But your blood is tainted, child. And that makes you dangerous." Aya looked at Katra and Simeon, who stood frozen in shock, their eyes wide with horror. She knew she'd betrayed them, but she also knew that she couldn't let them suffer for her mistakes. "Madame Evangeline," she said, her voice steady despite the turmoil raging within her. "I can be useful to you. I can help you retrieve the Scythan artifact. But I need something in return." Evangeline raised an eyebrow. "And what is that?" "My freedom," Aya said, her voice unwavering. "And the freedom of my friends." Evangeline laughed, a cold, cruel sound that echoed through the chamber. "Freedom? You think I would ever grant you freedom? You are a Morska now, child. You belong to us." Aya's eyes flashed with anger. "You can't hold me here forever. My family will come looking for me. They will demand my return." "And what will they do when they find you?" Evangeline countered. "They will find you a witch, consorting with the darkest of entities. They will find you a traitor to your class, to your family, to your country." Aya felt a wave of despair wash over her. She was trapped. She was a prisoner of the Morska, with no hope of escape. "Think about it," she said, her voice barely a whisper. "You need me. I can help you retrieve the artifact. You can use me as leverage against my family. But if you kill me, you lose that leverage. And you lose a valuable asset." Evangeline studied her for a long moment, her eyes cold and calculating. Then, she nodded slowly. "Very well," she said. "You have made your case. But know this, child. If you betray me, if you attempt to escape, you will regret it. I will make you regret it." She turned to her guards. "Take them to the cells. And make sure they are well fed. We have a long journey ahead of us." As Aya was led away, she looked back at Katra and Simeon, their faces etched with fear and betrayal. She knew she'd broken their trust, but she also knew that she'd done what she had to do to survive. The pocket watch in Simeon's waistcoat ticked loudly, marking each tense second as they were dragged down the stone corridor, deeper into the underhold. Aya could feel his eyes on her, filled with a mixture of anger and disappointment. She knew she'd let him down, but she also knew that he would eventually understand. She hoped. The door to the cells slammed shut behind them, plunging them into darkness. Aya closed her eyes, trying to shut out the sound of the lock clicking into place. She was a prisoner now, and she had no idea what the future held. But she was alive. And as long as she was alive, there was still hope.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] The response presents a well-crafted scene that largely adheres to the prompt's requirements, though with some notable shortcomings. The writer successfully creates a Victorian-inspired whalepunk fantasy world with elements of gothic horror, focusing on Aya's confrontation with the guild leader. The adherence to instructions is strong, with the writer hitting all the required story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked, the trio are taken prisoner, and Aya attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The piece is written in third-person past tense as requested, includes Aya's internal monologue, and incorporates dialogue. The word count is appropriate, and the writer avoids creating a fight scene. The characters' actions are generally believable within the established context. Aya's attempt to negotiate for her and her friends' freedom feels natural given her aristocratic background and the dire situation. However, the characters lack true depth and nuance. Katra and Simeon, in particular, remain underdeveloped, serving primarily as background elements rather than fully realized characters with their own motivations and reactions. They have minimal dialogue and their personalities are only superficially sketched. The prose is competent but occasionally veers into cliché and melodrama. Phrases like "her voice like silk laced with venom" and "her eyes boring into Aya's" are somewhat overwrought. The dialogue, while serviceable, sometimes feels stilted and expository rather than authentic to the characters. Lines like "You are a Morska now, child. You belong to us" come across as generic villain speech rather than distinctive to Madame Evangeline's character. The worldbuilding elements are intriguing but underdeveloped. References to "immateria magick," the "Scythan artifact," and the Morska guild create a sense of a larger world, but these elements aren't fully integrated into the narrative. The writer mentions that "men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood," but doesn't fully explore this theme within the scene. The imagery and descriptive quality are adequate but inconsistent. The opening description of the underhold creates a suitably atmospheric setting, but the physical descriptions become less detailed as the scene progresses. The writer tells us about Aya's "dark energy" but doesn't show us how it manifests or feels to her. The ending feels somewhat rushed and convenient. Aya's negotiation succeeds too easily, with Evangeline quickly agreeing to keep them alive with minimal resistance. This undercuts the tension built throughout the scene and feels like an easy way out rather than a earned resolution. Overall, while the piece successfully creates an intriguing scenario and follows the prompt's requirements, it lacks the depth, nuance, and distinctive voice that would elevate it to truly exceptional creative writing. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 14 Nuanced Characters: 11 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13 Elegant Prose: 12 Emotionally Engaging: 13 Emotionally Complex: 11 Coherent: 16 Meandering: 5 Weak Dialogue: 8 Tell-Don't-Show: 7 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8 Amateurish: 6 Purple Prose: 7 Overwrought: 6 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8 Unearned Transformations: 4 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12 Sentences Flow Naturally: 14 Overall Reader Engagement: 14 Overall Impression: 13
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 14.0, Nuanced Characters: 11.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 15.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 13.0, Elegant Prose: 12.0, Emotionally Engaging: 13.0, Emotionally Complex: 11.0, Coherent: 16.0, Meandering: 5.0, Weak Dialogue: 8.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 7.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 8.0, Amateurish: 6.0, Purple Prose: 7.0, Overwrought: 6.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 8.0, Unearned Transformations: 4.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 12.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 14.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 14.0, Overall Impression: 13.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 43.7
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The air in the bar is thick with the smell of sweat, stale beer, and cheap cologne. Spike Spiegel sits alone at the counter, nursing a glass of whiskey. The neon sign outside casts a sickly green glow over the room, illuminating the grime on the walls and the bored expressions of the few patrons scattered around. He’s been here for hours, waiting, watching. He’s been waiting for a long time. A woman enters, pushing through the swinging doors with a force that rattles the glasses behind the bar. She’s short, compact, and dressed in a way that screams trouble. Her black crop top barely contains her breasts, and her denim shorts are so short they’re practically nonexistent. Her right arm is covered in a vibrant dragon tattoo, and she carries two pistols holstered on her hips. Revy. Spike raises an eyebrow, taking in the scene. He’s seen a lot of women in his life, but this one…this one is different. There’s a feral edge to her, a coiled tension that makes him want to both approach and avoid her. She strides to the bar, her heels clicking sharply on the sticky floor. “Whiskey. Neat.” Her voice is rough, like sandpaper, and she doesn't bother to look at the bartender. Spike watches her, fascinated, as she downs the drink in one gulp. He takes a long drag from his cigarette, the cherry glowing in the dim light. “You waiting for someone?” she asks, her eyes fixed on him. He shrugs, exhaling a plume of smoke. “Maybe. Maybe not.” “You look like you’re waiting for someone who isn’t coming.” Spike smiles, a sad, knowing smile. “You’d be surprised.” Revy snorts. “Yeah, I wouldn’t.” She orders another whiskey. They sit in silence for a while, the only sounds the clinking of glasses and the low hum of the jukebox. Spike studies her, noticing the way she fidgets with her gun holsters, the way her eyes dart around the room, constantly scanning for threats. He knows that look. He’s seen it in the mirror. “You a bounty hunter?” she asks, finally breaking the silence. “Something like that,” Spike replies, taking another sip of his whiskey. “You got a name?” “Spike.” “Revy.” She holds out her hand, and he shakes it briefly. Her grip is surprisingly strong. “You here for the same thing I am?” he asks. She nods, her eyes narrowed. “Yeah. Ricardo’s got a bounty on a guy named Tanaka. Says he stole something valuable. I’m guessing you got the same intel.” Spike nods. “Seems so.” “So, we’re competitors, then?” He shrugs. “Depends on how you look at it. We could work together, split the bounty.” Revy scoffs. “You think I’d trust you?” “Why not?” “Because you look like a guy who’d shoot me in the back the second you got what you wanted.” “And you look like a guy who’d shoot me in the face for looking at you the wrong way.” She grins, a flash of teeth that are surprisingly white against her dark skin. “You got that right.” The bartender slides another whiskey across the counter to Revy. She downs it in one gulp and slams the glass down. “So, what’s your plan?” she asks. Spike leans back in his stool. “I’m thinking we hit Tanaka’s place tonight. He’s got a warehouse down by the docks. Should be easy enough to find.” “Easy for you, maybe,” Revy says. “I’m not exactly known for my subtlety.” “Then we’ll make it loud.” Spike smiles. “You got a problem with that?” Revy shrugs. “Not really.” They finish their drinks and head out into the night. The air is thick and humid, the streets slick with rain. They walk in silence for a while, the only sound their footsteps and the occasional passing car. “You know, for someone who’s supposed to be a bounty hunter, you don’t seem very interested in getting paid,” Revy says, breaking the silence. “I’m not really in it for the money,” Spike replies. “It’s more of a…hobby.” Revy laughs. “A hobby? You’re joking, right?” “Nope.” “So, what do you do for a living, then?” “I used to be a syndicate enforcer,” Spike says. “Before I decided I didn’t want to be part of that anymore.” Revy’s eyes widen. “You’re kidding.” “Nope.” “So, you’re a killer.” “Used to be,” Spike says. “Now I’m just trying to stay alive.” They reach the docks and head towards the warehouse. It’s a sprawling, dilapidated building, surrounded by piles of crates and shipping containers. The only light comes from a single bare bulb hanging from the ceiling. Spike signals Revy to take point. She nods and moves forward, her pistols drawn. She kicks open the door and steps inside, firing a burst of shots into the darkness. The warehouse is filled with Tanaka’s men. They return fire, and the room erupts in a hail of bullets. Spike ducks behind a crate, firing his own weapon. He moves with a grace and precision that belies his laid-back demeanor, taking down enemy after enemy. Revy is a whirlwind of motion, her pistols blazing. She dances through the gunfire, dodging bullets and returning fire with deadly accuracy. She’s like a demon unleashed, a force of pure destruction. Spike watches her, mesmerized by her skill. He’s seen a lot of fighters in his life, but he’s never seen anyone like her. They clear the warehouse, leaving a trail of bodies in their wake. Tanaka is nowhere to be found. “Where’d he go?” Revy asks, reloading her pistols. “He must have had an escape route,” Spike replies. “Let’s check the back.” They find Tanaka hiding in a small office at the back of the warehouse. He’s armed with a shotgun, but he’s no match for Revy and Spike. Spike disarms him with a swift kick to the knee, while Revy blows his eardrums out with a double tap from her pistols. “Ricardo’s going to be thrilled,” Revy says, cuffing Tanaka’s hands behind his back. “Yeah, I’m sure he will,” Spike replies. They leave Tanaka tied up in the office and head back to the docks. The rain has stopped, and the moon is shining brightly. “So, what now?” Revy asks. “We collect our bounty and go our separate ways,” Spike says. “Like we always do.” Revy looks at him, her eyes filled with a mixture of anger and desire. “You know, I don’t like being used.” Spike shrugs. “I didn’t use you.” “You just…used me.” “I didn’t,” Spike insists. “We were partners. We got the job done.” Revy shakes her head. “You’re lying.” Spike doesn’t respond. He knows she’s right. He used her, just like he’s used everyone else in his life. He just didn’t want her to know it. “I’m going to collect the bounty,” Revy says. “You can wait here if you want.” She turns and walks away, leaving Spike standing alone in the moonlight. He watches her go, a pang of regret in his chest. He wants to stop her, to tell her that he’s sorry, but he knows it would be useless. He follows her to Ricardo’s office. The room is opulent, filled with expensive furniture and artwork. Ricardo sits behind a large mahogany desk, a cigar clenched between his teeth. “Well, well, well,” Ricardo says, looking up from his paperwork. “Look what the cat dragged in. Two of the best bounty hunters in the business.” He hands Revy an envelope filled with cash. “Here’s your share, Two Hands. And here’s yours, Spike Spiegel.” Spike takes the envelope and pockets the money. He doesn’t even bother to count it. “So, what are you two going to do now?” Ricardo asks. Revy shrugs. “I’m going back to Roanapur.” “And you, Spike?” Spike smiles, a sad, knowing smile. “I’m going wherever the wind takes me.” He turns and walks out of the office, leaving Ricardo and Revy behind. He heads towards a nearby motel, the neon sign flickering in the rain. He checks into a room and sits on the bed, smoking a cigarette. He hears a knock on the door. He opens it to find Revy standing in the hallway, her eyes blazing. “What do you want?” he asks. “I want you to tell me the truth,” she says. Spike sighs. “I already told you. I didn’t use you.” “Don’t lie to me, Spike.” He looks at her, his eyes filled with regret. “Okay, you’re right. I did use you. I’m sorry.” Revy steps into the room and slams the door behind her. “You’re sorry? That’s it?” “What do you want me to say?” Spike asks. “I want you to tell me why.” Spike looks away, unable to meet her gaze. “I don’t know.” “You’re lying.” “I’m not.” Revy walks towards him, her eyes burning with anger. She grabs his collar and pulls him close. “You’re a coward, Spike Spiegel. You’re afraid of getting close to anyone.” “Maybe I am,” he says. “Why?” He doesn’t answer. Revy pushes him against the wall and leans in close. Her breath is hot on his face. “I know you’re hurting, Spike. I know you’ve been through a lot. But you don’t have to be alone.” She kisses him, a hard, desperate kiss. He responds, his own desire overriding his fear. They kiss for a long time, their bodies pressed together. When they finally break apart, Spike is breathing heavily. “What are you doing?” he asks. “I don’t know,” Revy says. “I just…I felt like it.” She leans in again, but Spike pushes her away. “No,” he says. “We can’t do this.” Revy looks at him, hurt and confusion in her eyes. “Why not?” “Because it’s not real,” Spike says. “It’s just…a moment. And moments don’t last.” “Maybe they don’t have to,” Revy says. Spike shakes his head. “No. It’s better this way. We’re better off apart.” He turns and walks towards the window, staring out at the rain-slicked streets below. He knows he’s right, but it doesn’t make it any easier. He’s afraid of getting close to anyone, but he’s even more afraid of losing someone he cares about. Revy stands behind him, her arms crossed. “You’re a fool, Spike Spiegel,” she says. “You’re throwing away something good.” He doesn’t respond. He just keeps staring out the window, his face a mask of regret. Revy sighs and walks towards the door. “I’m going to regret this,” she says. She opens the door and steps out into the hallway. Spike watches her go, his heart aching. He knows he’ll never see her again, and he knows he’ll regret it for the rest of his life. He turns away from the window and sits back on the bed, smoking another cigarette. He closes his eyes and tries to forget about Revy, but her image is burned into his mind. He’s already died once, he thinks. Maybe this is the second time.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece attempts to create a crossover between Spike Spiegel from Cowboy Bebop and Revy from Black Lagoon, but falls short in several key areas. The characterization is superficial and inconsistent. While the writer includes some surface-level traits (Revy's outfit, Spike's laid-back attitude), both characters feel like watered-down versions of themselves. Revy lacks her trademark explosive anger and vulgar language that defines her character. Her dialogue is surprisingly tame and generic. Spike's philosophical fatalism and complex past are mentioned but not meaningfully integrated into the story. The promised "unresolved sexual tension" feels forced rather than organic. The characters move from professional distrust to a sudden kiss without sufficient buildup. Their attraction isn't convincingly established through their interactions, making their eventual physical encounter feel unmotivated. The action sequence at the warehouse is rushed and generic. Despite both characters being known for their distinctive fighting styles, the gunfight lacks the choreographic detail and unique flair that would make it memorable. Revy's dual-wielding "Two Hands" technique is mentioned but not vividly depicted. The dialogue is particularly weak. Neither character speaks in a way that captures their distinctive voices from their respective series. Spike's laconic wit and Revy's profanity-laden outbursts are absent, replaced by generic exchanges that could belong to any action characters. The narrative structure is disjointed. The story jumps from the bar to the warehouse raid to the motel room without smooth transitions. The conflict with Tanaka is resolved too easily and feels like an afterthought rather than the central plot element it should be. The ending attempts emotional complexity but feels contrived. Spike's rejection of Revy doesn't align with his established character motivations, and his internal monologue about regret comes across as melodramatic rather than genuine. The prose is serviceable but lacks the stylistic flair that would elevate the piece. Descriptions are often generic ("the air is thick with the smell of sweat, stale beer, and cheap cologne") and fail to create a vivid sense of place or atmosphere. Overall, this piece misses opportunities to truly capture what makes these characters compelling and to create meaningful interaction between them. It relies too heavily on telling rather than showing their personalities and fails to deliver on the promised tension and complexity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 12 Believable Character Actions: 8 Nuanced Characters: 7 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 10 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 9 Elegant Prose: 8 Emotionally Engaging: 7 Emotionally Complex: 6 Coherent: 11 Meandering: 12 Weak Dialogue: 14 Tell-Don't-Show: 13 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13 Amateurish: 12 Purple Prose: 8 Overwrought: 10 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 13 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 7 Sentences Flow Naturally: 11 Overall Reader Engagement: 8 Overall Impression: 8
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 12.0, Believable Character Actions: 8.0, Nuanced Characters: 7.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 10.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 9.0, Elegant Prose: 8.0, Emotionally Engaging: 7.0, Emotionally Complex: 6.0, Coherent: 11.0, Meandering: 12.0, Weak Dialogue: 14.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 13.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 13.0, Amateurish: 12.0, Purple Prose: 8.0, Overwrought: 10.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 13.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 7.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 11.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 8.0, Overall Impression: 8.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 48.2
Prompt:
Fok Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wind occasionally rustled the pine trees, sounding almost like faint whispers. It was late May, but the air was sharp and cold, clinging to my skin as I sat on the moss-covered mound. Astrid sat beside me, her dark hair pulled back in a messy bun, her face illuminated by the sliver of a moon. We were on the edge of the village, on a burial mound that Astrid’s grandmother had told her was ancient, older than the village itself. I hadn’t wanted to be here. I hadn’t wanted to be in this village, in this house, anywhere near Astrid, but she’d been relentless. “It’s just a game, Linnea,” she’d said, her voice low and insistent. “It’s just a bit of fun. You’ll see. It’s not scary.” Astrid had been my lifeline since we moved here. My parents, both academics, had taken the transfer to the university in Luleå in their stride, excited by the research opportunities. I, however, had been ripped from my friends, my school, my life in Stockholm. Astrid, with her wild eyes and dark clothes, had been the only person who’d reached out. She’d shown me the hidden swimming holes, the best places to pick berries, and the secret trails that led through the forest. She’d also introduced me to her grandmother’s stories of the old ways, of the Sami people who had once lived here, of the spirits that lingered in the woods and the mountains. Tonight, she’d convinced me to participate in Útiseta, a midnight ritual that Astrid claimed her grandmother had taught her. “It’s about connecting with the knowledge of the ancestors,” she’d explained, her voice hushed. “You sit here, at the top of the mound, and you listen. They’ll tell you things.” I’d scoffed. “Like what? Who’s going to tell me things?” “The spirits,” Astrid had said, her eyes gleaming in the dim light. “The ones who are buried here. They’re all around us, Linnea. You just have to open yourself up to them.” I hadn't believed her, but Astrid had been so persuasive, so convincing. And I’d been so lonely. So, I’d agreed. Astrid had prepared for the ritual with a seriousness that unnerved me. She’d gathered birch twigs, which she’d bound together with strips of linen. She’d lit a small fire in a stone circle we’d built on the mound, the smoke curling upwards into the night sky. She’d made us each a cup of tea from wild herbs, the scent of pine needles and something bitter and earthy filling the air. “Drink it,” she’d said, handing me the cup. “It’ll help you connect.” I’d sipped it, the taste strange and unfamiliar, but I hadn’t complained. I didn’t want to disappoint her. “Now, we wait,” Astrid had said, sitting down beside me. “And we listen.” The wind picked up, rattling the birch twigs and sending a shiver down my spine. I wrapped my arms around myself, trying to ward off the cold. Astrid didn’t seem to notice. She was staring out at the forest, her face blank. “Do you hear anything?” I asked, my voice barely a whisper. Astrid shook her head. “Not yet. It takes time. You have to be patient.” I waited, straining my ears. All I could hear was the wind, and the crackling of the fire. The silence was oppressive, heavy with anticipation. Suddenly, Astrid gasped.
